- A Police Inspector is being de- tained for extorting money forcefully from an alien. - A Police Inspector is being de- tained for extorting money forcefully from an alien.

The Inspector, Bebatunde Ajayi, attached to anti-robbery squad of Sango-Ota police division in Ogun State was clamped into cell on Monday 12 December, 1994. The Inspector, Bebatunde Ajayi, attached to anti-robbery squad of Sango-Ota police division in Ogun State was clamped into cell on Monday 12 December, 1994.

Stern-looking mobile policemen have now been drafted to guard the ilupeju home ofWorks and Housing Minister, Alhaji Lateel Jakande, following threats by unle dentified persons to bomb the place. Police source told PMNews that intelligent reports indicated that plans have been con- cluded by a group to carry out the attack last month but for the alertness of the police. South African President Nelson Mandela said in an inter- view published in London yesterday that he would remain in office until the next general elections in 1999, but would likely step down afterwards". I am the servant of the people. i will continue for as long as they want me to," Mandela told the Daily Telegraphic South African President Nelson Mandela said in an inter- view published in London yesterday that he would remain in office until the next general elections in 1999, but would likely step down afterwards". I am the servant of the people. i will continue for as long as they want me to," Mandela told the Daily Telegraphic

P "But I must add that I am 76," he said. "I don't feel thatat the end of the next five years, a man of my age would like to continue to lead the country." P "But I must add that I am 76," he said. "I don't feel thatat the end of the next five years, a man of my age would like to continue to lead the country."

Asked about criticism of the slow pace of social reform in South Africa, Mandela said, "I don't think thatis criticism to be taken seriously. "We had to allay fears of whites to ensure the transition process took place smoothly, said Mandela. "If we had not done so, the civil war that was threatening would have broken out." He called the progress his gov- ernment had brought about "fantastic," saying "we have done very well. We have introduced a culture of humanrights, of transpar- ency and accountability..." = Asked about criticism of the slow pace of social reform in South Africa, Mandela said, "I don't think thatis criticism to be taken seriously. ... Tells How He Smuggled Autobiography outofPrison ... Tells How He Smuggled Autobiography outofPrison

President Nelson Mandela wenton television yesterday the eve of the release of his autobi- ography "Long Walk to. Freedom, to tell how the book was written clandestinely while he was in prison. President Nelson Mandela wenton television yesterday the eve of the release of his autobi- ography "Long Walk to. Freedom, to tell how the book was written clandestinely while he was in prison.

Interviewed by public South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC), Mandela related how chap- ters of the book were reproduced in small print and then sinuggled out of prison by fellow prisoner Mac Maharaj, now Transport Min- ister. "I had no historical records to check the facts. 1 used them (Sisulu and Katharada) as my reference and they did wonderful work," he sald. "When I had-completed the book, it was reduced to small type and smuggled out of prison." "When I had-completed the book, it was reduced to small type and smuggled out of prison."

The book teils of Mandela's birth into a Xhosa royal household, his flights from Transkel to Johannesburg to avoid an arranged marriage, and his first contacts with city life and white overlords, The book teils of Mandela's birth into a Xhosa royal household, his flights from Transkel to Johannesburg to avoid an arranged marriage, and his first contacts with city life and white overlords,
